content:
A group of biology students are interested in the effect of pH on enzyme activity. They measure the activity of enzymes A and B at various pH values and plot their data, as shown in the graph below.

[[☃ image 1]]

**A solution of enzyme B has a pH of $8$. Based on the graph, which pH change would result in higher enzyme activity?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: The x axis on the line graph is labeled pH and has labels at 2,4,6,8,10, 12, and 14. The y axis is labeled enzyme activity. There are no marks on the y axis. There are 2 colored lines on the graph, with a key labeled A blue line and B red line. Line A begins at pH 2 and the origin of the y axis, rises sharply and peaks at pH 6, then declines sharply and returns to the y axis origin at pH 10. Line B begins at pH 6 and the origin of the y axis, rises sharply and peaks at pH 10, then declines sharply and returns to the y axis at pH 14. The peaks of Line A and Line B are at the same enzyme activity level.

choices.content: decreasing the pH of the solution to $4$
choices.clue: According to the graph, enzyme B is inactive at pH $4$. So, decreasing the pH of the solution from $8$ to $4$ would *not* result in higher enzyme activity.

choices.content: decreasing the pH of the solution to $6$
choices.clue: According to the graph, enzyme B is *less*, not more, active at pH $6$ than at pH $8$. So, decreasing the pH of the solution from $8$ to $6$ would *not* result in higher enzyme activity.

choices.content: increasing the pH of the solution to $10$
choices.clue: According to the graph, enzyme B is more active at pH $10$ than at pH $8$. So, increasing the pH of the solution from $8$ to $10$ would result in higher enzyme activity.

choices.content: increasing the pH of the solution to $12$
choices.clue: According to the graph, enzyme B is slightly *less*, not more, active at pH $12$ than at pH $8$. So, increasing the pH of the solution from $8$ to $12$ would *not* result in higher enzyme activity.
